messageBody:
On 12/22/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> Hi David,
>
> On 12/22/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > > Sharing expensive immutable state in the same test class is a totally
> > > harmless and extremely common scenario that I wish JUnit made easier to
> > > implement (i.e. no statics and no special runner).
> >
> > Requiring expensive immutable state in a unit test is harmful to unit
> > design. (In my opinion, not thinking about unit tests and system
> > tests as different things is harmful to unit and system design.)
>
>
> Agreed, but how about people who are using JUnit to do functional testing?
> What do you tell them? Use TestNG? :-)

If they want. If they're interested in what I do, I use JUnit, but in
a different way. For example, I'll use the same Eclipse instance
throughout, or use a different runner like
@RunWith(OneInstance.class). These aren't things that I do with the
_unit tests_, or, to use another name, _developer tests_, that I run
at least 5-10 times an hour.

Do you have a test suite that you can run at least 5-10 times an hour
on your current project? I have to assume that it doesn't involve
humongous data structures, because constructing one of those even once
can take enough time to break a train of thought.

I'll respond to your other question on the original poster's thread.

David Saff
